entry.title: Re: Where can I find documentation on changed process IDs...
entry.content:
Hi @Kuklik 

Yes, there have been reports that some internal process IDs for transactions related to electricity supply changes were adjusted by adding 50 to previous IDs for example start of delivery changing from 1010 to 1060 after June 6th. This aligns with system updates to accommodate the accelerated supplier change process.

However, note that SAP does not publicly document such internal process ID changes in the usual release notes or help portals in a straightforward way.

For any official SAP documentation on this update, I suggest you check the SAP Help Portal under latest release and legislative updates for Energy and Utilities sectors, or specific SAP Notes related to the June 6, 2025 regulatory changes.

One relevant source mention’s changes in the MaBiS process effective June 6, 2025, requiring the exclusive use of APERAK messages to confirm supplier switches within 24 hours, which indicates backend process updates but does not explicitly list process ID shifts.

To get exact documented process ID changes, I recommend raising a message with SAP Support referencing the June 6, 2025 legislation impact or checking with SAP’s legislative content support for Energy and Utilities.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Download Manager Login issue
entry.content:
The error 'The basket content could be read. Verify your logon credentials or private certificate key and try again.' typically occurs due to an incorrect password being used in the SAP Download Manager. 

To resolve this issue, please ensure that you are using your S-user password in the SAP Download Manager, rather than your Universal ID (UID) password, which is specifically for accessing SAP for Me. 

Please kindly note that the SAP Download Manager does not support SAP Universal ID password, as explained in KBA 3016110 - Software download issues while using SAP Universal ID - SAP Download Manager. 

If you are unsure of the password for your individual S-user ID, we recommend you using the Forgot My Password function to reset your S-user ID password by following the steps below:

  1. Go to Forgot My Password page
  2. Enter your S-user ID: S00xxxxxxxx
  3. Click on Continue button
  4. An e-mail will be sent from SAP ID Service (ias@notifications.sap.com) to the e-mail address registered for the user.
  5. Open the e-mail to find the password reset link.

More detail on how to reset an S-user password can be found in 1808560 - How to reset an S-user ID password - SAP for Me

Hope this information is helpful to you!

If you have any questions or need further assistance, please feel free to contact us.

Best regards,
Judy
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: sap_ cml loans_ condition A_interest_arrears disappe...
entry.content:
Hi @palmeram123 

Based on the information you provided, here are a few considerations and potential action to help you resolve the issue.

Please note that in SAP FS-CML mortgage loan contracts, the A_interest_arrears condition may disappear after reopening if:

It has no values or valid dates or empty conditions are hidden by default.

It is not enabled in the loan product type’s condition group configuration.

User lacks authorization to maintain it post‑creation.

Its validity lies outside the visible period.

I recommend you consider doing the following:

  • First, ensure to enter valid values and effective dates before saving.
  • Then confirm the desired condition is assigned and active in the product type/condition group customizing.
  • Make sure to verify your user authorizations and reinsert missing conditions manually if needed.
  • Finally, you can re-calculate or simulate cash flow to ensure it persists.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to use underdelivery tolerence in project stock r...
entry.content:
Hello @RaghavanKathamuthu 

I don't think underdelivery tolerance can work in MTP environment. See the documentation of the "Underdelivery Tolerance" field in lot sizing procedure settings:

The functionality needs to be able to link a planned order to a sales order item to verify planned order quantity against sales order item underdelivery tolerance. Such a direct link exists in MTO, but not in MTP.

Your test case looks nice but it is very simplistic:

You can have multiple sales order with different underdelivery tolerances and multiple planned orders under the same MRP planning segment (project stock). How would you link a planned order to a sales order to verify the tolerance in such a case?

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: Inter company outgoing payment on A/P down payment -D...
entry.content:
Hello @Nambi1234 

Hi @palmeram123 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, delegation is possible for intercompany outgoing payments on A/P down payments in SAP for example through Centralized Payments in Intercompany Integration. One company or branch can process payments on behalf of another, including down payments.

However, for this to happen the following must be in place:

First, centralized payment or intercompany workflows must be configured.

Ensure user roles or authorizations permit delegated payment processing.

Finally, ensure the system posts correct accounting entries for both entities.

For a successful integration, a configuration of workflows and authorizations is key to enabling this scenario.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: AI-Assisted Chart Summary in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce the General Availability of the AI-Assisted Chart Summary feature in SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft PowerPoint.
This new powerful capability is available as part of the Q3 2025 release.

 

What Is It?

The AI-Assisted Chart Summary leverages generative AI to automatically generate concise, human-readable summaries of SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) charts embedded in your PowerPoint presentations. Whether you're preparing for a meeting or sharing insights with stakeholders, this feature helps you communicate key takeaways faster and more clearly.

 

 

 

Benefits

  • Save Time: No more manually interpreting charts and writing manual summaries. AI-assisted chart summary delivers generated summary in seconds.
  • Enhance Clarity and boost accessibility: Summaries are crafted in natural language, making complex data accessible to everyone
  • Accelerate Decisions: By surfacing trends and key points instantly, users can act faster and smarter.
  • Stay Current: Summaries can be regenerated on demand to reflect any changes in the underlying chart data, ensuring your insights are always up to date.

 

How It Works

When working in SAC add-in for Microsoft PowerPoint, simply select a chart and click on “Generate Summary” button. The generated text is inserted in the current slide as an editable comment, allowing you to tailor the message if needed. And if your data changes? Just regenerate the summary with a click—no need to start from scratch.

 

 

 

Licensing & Availability

This feature is part of the broader AI-Assisted Features suite in SAC and requires:

  • A valid SAC license (BI or Planning)
  • An AI Units SKU contract

AI Units are consumed as the feature is used. Pricing and consumption details are available via the SAP Business AI Catalog.

 

Thanks for your interest. We hope you will enjoy using this new capability and look forward to your feedback.

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - August 2025
entry.content:
IDC – Saas Path

Based on the 2025 IDC SaaS Path Executive Summary and Vendor Ratings Reports, key trends, buyer priorities, and vendor performance for Procurement applications—including SAP Ariba and its main competitors—are as follows:

Key Industry Trends and Buyer Priorities in Procurement

  • Value Drivers and Challenges:
    • Procurement buyers most value solutions that enable proactive spend analytics, cost savings, and effective procurement analytics.
    • Persistent pain points include analyzing spend data and sustaining savings; integration and analytics capabilities are highly sought after.
    • Tail Spend Management is the least cited challenge—likely because teams are overwhelmed with risk, tariffs, and sustainability, not because the problem is solved.
  • Preferred Vendor Attributes:

Buyers in procurement rank these as the top attributes in evaluating SaaS vendors:

  • Trusted brand (32.0%)
  • Ease of implementation (27.3%)
  • Ease of integration (25.3%)
  • Superior features/functionality (27.3%)
  • Robust data security (28.0%)
  • AI-driven capabilities (33.3%)
  • Data management capabilities (24.0%)

Ease of integration, expected value, and built-in analytics are distinguishing needs.

  • Market Outlook:
    • 82% of organizations plan to consolidate applications to fewer providers, indicating a market with significant churn and switching potential.
    • 23%–29% of procurement users plan to switch vendors within two years

SAP Ariba: Distinct Strengths and Weaknesses

Strengths:

  • Recognized for a trusted brand, reliable implementation, integration, and robust security.
  • Among procurement SaaS providers, SAP Ariba is seen as delivering strong overall value and performance across major satisfaction metrics.

Weaknesses:

  • Still faces challenges with cost and fees, as well as somewhat infrequent feature releases compared to certain competitors.
  • Buyers cite “price increases not accompanied by value” as an issue but at a lower frequency than some other vendors.
  • While not a top AI leader compared to Coupa, SAP Ariba’s AI-driven capabilities are seen as strong and competitive

Deloitte CPO Report

The 2025 Deloitte Global Chief Procurement Officer (CPO) Survey states that procurement is facing rising complexity and external pressures (e.g., inflation, trade wars, supply disruptions, and regulatory demands) while leveraging digital transformation, especially Generative AI (GenAI), to create value.

Key takeaways for procurement leaders:

Procurement is being asked to deliver more value amid resource constraints; digital and AI adoption are seen as essential to achieve more with less. CPOs are significantly increasing investment in procurement technology, averaging 20% of budget (nearly double 2023).

Top 2025 organisational priorities are:

  • Margin improvement via cost reduction.
  • Operational efficiency.
  • Digital transformation and GenAI.
  • Revenue uplift in a stagflationary market.
  • Risk management to protect supply lines.

GenAI adoption is expanding rapidly, especially for spend analytics, contract management, RFx generation, and supplier risk identification. Main barriers include internal silos, competing priorities, talent/skills gaps (especially digital skills), and organizational complexity. Data quality and governance are top internal and external risks with GenAI implementation.

Effective risk management now focuses on bolstering supply chain resilience, increasing visibility, activating alternative sources, and leveraging AI in third-party risk management and contract analytics.

The report identifies that the strategic focus areas that support these organisational priorities include:

  • Digital transformation (the single biggest value driver for 2025).
  • Renegotiation with existing suppliers to address volatility and cost inflation.
  • Greater supplier collaboration to unlock win-win opportunities.
  • Consolidating spend for efficiency and reduced complexity.
  • Enhancing demand management to align procurement closely with changing business needs.
  • Developing supply chain resiliency as a continued response to global trade and operational shock.

Talent remains critical: competitive advantage will belong to organizations that attract, develop, and retain digitally skilled procurement professionals, while also implementing agile workforce and managed service models.

Ardent Partners State of the CPO 2025

Similar to the Deloitte report, the Ardent partners, CPO rising report finds that procurement and business is being shaped by global uncertainty, persistent market volatility, and an accelerating wave of technological disruption—especially around AI and automation.

Key points

Nearly 60% of CPOs report that 2025 is marked by "great uncertainty" due to geopolitical tensions, shifting trade policies, inflation, and supply chain fragility.

38% of CPOs cite budget constraints as the number one obstacle to improved procurement performance, followed closely by misaligned processes, incomplete technology, and difficult stakeholder engagement.

Almost half of CPOs are using AI in some form, mostly through integrated or standalone systems rather than fully embedded suites and 73% believe AI will have a significant or transformational impact on procurement within 2-3 years, seeing it as a prime lever for productivity.

Top Priorities: Delivering cost savings (71%), managing supply risk (42%), and driving digital transformation (34%) are the main CPO focuses.

Comparison between Deloitte & Ardent Partners

As these two reports came out in the same month, there are some consistent themes:

  1. Heightened Uncertainty and Complexity

Both identify 2025 as a year of significant uncertainty, driven by factors such as inflation, volatile tariffs, supply chain disruptions, geopolitical instability, and evolving regulations. CPOs face more external complexity, requiring resilience and adaptability from their procurement teams.

  1. Cost Savings Remain the Top Priority

“Delivering cost savings” is cited as the foremost priority by CPOs in both reports. Protecting or improving margins, especially against inflation and tariffs, is central to the procurement value proposition.

  1. Managing Supply Risk and Ensuring Continuity

Risk management is a core focus. Both reports emphasize proactive risk management—through better data visibility, supplier diversification, and scenario planning—as key to weathering supply disruptions and achieving “supply assurance.”

  1. Digital Transformation and AI Adoption

There is universal agreement on the strategic imperative of digital transformation, with significant emphasis on automation, digital procurement tools, and AI (especially GenAI). Both note technology as an enabler for efficiency, better analytics, workload management, and strategic agility.

  1. Talent & Skills Development

Both highlight persistent talent shortages, especially in digital and analytics skills. The need for upskilling, attracting digitally-savvy talent, and focusing on training is prominent.

  1. Collaboration & Integration

Internal collaboration, stakeholder engagement, and supplier partnerships are recognized as crucial for procurement to achieve enterprise-wide objectives in both documents.

Fairmarkt – AI Market Survey

The 2025 Fairmarkit AI Market Survey Report aims to spotlight the growing pressure on procurement teams to adopt generative AI (GenAI), highlighting key challenges such as economic uncertainty, rapid supplier-led AI adoption, internal resistance, and evolving skill requirements.

94% of suppliers are already using AI in negotiations, many procurement teams are lagging due to internal barriers and trust issues.

Despite 91% of organizations having executive mandates for AI adoption, over half face governance and compliance roadblocks, and 52% admit to not fully understanding GenAI

As 84% of leaders anticipate a recession by the end of 2025, pressure on procurement is intensifying, especially around cost controls and risk mitigation

The report emphasizes that AI is reshaping—not eliminating—jobs: 44% expect team growth, while 82% say data analysis and interpretation are now critical skills

Gartner Hype Cycle

Similar to many reports the Gartner "Hype Cycle for Procurement and Sourcing Solutions, 2025" highlights a rapidly evolving procurement technology landscape shaped by global disruptions, regulatory challenges, and accelerated technology adoption.

Key findings for procurement leaders include:

AI and Automation: Generative AI and Agentic AI are gaining traction, promising transformational benefits through automation, data-driven decision making, and proactive supplier and spend management. While GenAI has entered the Trough of Disillusionment due to mixed adoption results, it remains set to reach maturity in 2–5 years. Agentic AI, in its embryonic phase, is expected to bring autonomy and efficiency but requires organizational readiness and strong data foundations.

Emerging and Transformational Technologies: Autonomous procurement and orchestration platforms are poised to reshape processes, reduce costs, and realign procurement with strategic business goals. However, successful adoption depends on quality data, integration, and change management.

Supply Chain Visibility and Risk: Multitier supplier visibility and advanced risk management solutions cater to rising transparency mandates and supply chain disruptions but demand significant data collection and supplier engagement efforts.

Analytics and Digital Maturity: Predictive and prescriptive analytics, along with advanced contract analytics, support proactive, data-driven procurement but require robust data governance and specialized expertise.

At-a-Glance Table: Main Changes 2024 v 2025

Technology/Trend

2024 Status

2025 Status

Key Change/Trend

Generative AI for Procurement

Peak of Inflated Expectations (transformational)

Trough of Disillusionment (transformational), mixed ROI, evolving

Hype fades, real gains/limits emerge

Agentic AI for Procurement

Not present

Debuts at Innovation Trigger (transformational, embryonic maturity)

New, autonomous agent-based AI arrives

Procurement Orchestration Platforms

Emerging, lots of market confusion, few true platforms

Still transformational, more emerging vendors, integration remains hard

Category matures, clearer distinctions

Autonomous Procurement

On the Rise, embryonic, less than 1% penetration

Still transformational, still embryonic, slow mainstream move

More pilots, same maturity

Conversational AI

Adolescent, likely to be obsolete before plateau

Integrated/replaced by GenAI and agentic AI solutions

GenAI supplants old models

Supplier Risk Management, S2P Suites, RPA

Slope of Enlightenment, increasing adoption

Closer to plateau, proven ROI, wider adoption expected

More mainstream, safer investments

Category Management, Intake Management, Advanced Contract Analytics, Supplier Diversity

Emerging, low to moderate benefit

Still emerging, slow adoption

Stable, low-maturity space

 

BCG – Balancing Cost & Resilience

The Boston Consulting Group (BCG) article "Balancing Cost and Resilience: The New Supply Chain Challenge" outlines how procurement strategy must evolve to balance cost efficiency with supply chain resilience. Here are the main takeaways for procurement:

  1. Shift to a “Cost of Resilience” Mindset:
    Procurement must go beyond the old “cost is king” approach. Leaders now need to balance cost competitiveness with supply chain agility, recognizing that resilience (the ability to withstand and rapidly respond to shocks) often entails higher costs and greater complexity. Procurement strategies must explicitly address this tradeoff, incorporating risk and flexibility into sourcing and supplier decisions.
  2. Four Megatrends Shaping Procurement Decisions:
    • Economic Statecraft: Geopolitical tensions, new tariffs, and subsidies are reshaping trade flows and increasing sourcing risk—procurement must constantly assess and mitigate exposure to sudden policy changes.
    • Climate Risk: Extreme weather and climate events threaten major manufacturing and logistics hubs, requiring procurement teams to factor location-specific climate risk into sourcing and capacity decisions.
    • Manufacturing Talent Competition: Shortages of blue- and white-collar talent require procurement to monitor labor market trends and ensure supply base flexibility in attracting and retaining critical skills.
    • Robotics and Automation: Rapid adoption of robotics increases the need for supplier capability assessments. Procurement should consider automation investment when selecting or negotiating with suppliers.bcg
  3. Diversification and Redundancy:
    Procurement should avoid overconcentration by developing regional or local supply chains, dual/triple sourcing, and building redundancy into supplier networks. “Dual sourcing is becoming the minimum viable standard”—procurement should always have credible backup options for critical categories and encourage the use of supply chain brokers for additional flexibility.
  4. Strategic Supplier Collaboration:
    Adopting new models like contract manufacturing, joint ventures, and supply chain brokers can unlock shared capacity and geographic reach. Procurement should lead the identification and onboarding of such partners, negotiating shared production arrangements when internal scaling would be too costly.
  5. Upgraded Risk Management and Transparency:
    Procurement organizations need greater end-to-end visibility into their supplier base and the risks affecting them (e.g., geopolitical, climate, or labor risks), including deep tier suppliers. Implementing digital tools and KPIs that measure total procurement value—not just lowest unit cost—will facilitate better, risk-adjusted decisions.
  6. Automation and Network Design:
    Procurement must factor the level of automation at supplier sites into network design and site selection, ensuring that robotics adoption itself is resilient (i.e., not overly dependent on a single country’s technology). Supplier contracts and scorecards should assess automation capabilities and potential geo-specific risks from robotics supply.
  7. Climate and Labor Considerations in Procurement:
    Procurement must embed sustainability and labor risk into supplier scorecards and sourcing decisions. For high climate/exposure categories, strategies may include selecting suppliers in lower-risk geographies, building inventories, or supporting suppliers’ resilience investments.
  8. Evolving Talent Management in Procurement:
    Procurement leaders need to cultivate new capabilities, such as data analysis for risk modeling, regulatory and geopolitical awareness, and supplier innovation management. Partnering with HR to ensure talent pipelines and considering supplier location from a workforce availability angle will become increasingly important.
  9. Cascade KPIs Across the Supply Chain:
    Procurement should adopt—and require major suppliers to adopt—KPIs that track tradeoffs between cost, resilience, and compliance. This includes metrics for supplier concentration, time to switch suppliers, inventory buffers, and ESG compliance. Embedding this mindset across the supplier network fosters consistent risk management.

 

 

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: Re: Can we set multi scaled conditions in SAP TM Rate table?
entry.content:
Hi @LINGLINGLING_CN 

Sure, here are details you can consider. Please note, in SAP TM, the grouping strategy means defining a grouping rule in the calculation sheet.
To meet the 1 FU = 1 FO per DN requirement while pricing per lane/weight/day, you will have to do the following

  • First, you should group by From Location, To Location, and Calendar Day.
  • Thereafter, ensure to aggregate total FO weight for each lane/day.
  • Finally, apply the aggregated weight to the rate calculation, while keeping each FU as its own FO.

This will ensure consolidated pricing but maintains the one‑to‑one FU–FO setup.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Manufacturing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release introduces an array of novel features of which I would like to highlight the most important ones: 

  • Enabling use of custom fields in production routing as reference characteristics in advanced variant configuration
  • Integration of Change Documents
  • Import Sales Document Configuration
  • Export BOM Structure
  • User Authorization for Schedule Handover of Purchase Requisitions
  • Capacity Scheduling Board
  • Capacity Scheduling Table
  • AI-Assisted Processing of Incoming Quality Certificates with SAP Document AI

Find my short manufacturing highlight video with Jaz the avatar here:  

 

 

Production Engineering

Enabling use of custom fields in production routing as reference characteristics in advanced variant configuration

You can now map the Advanced Variant Configuration characteristic values linked to custom fields of Production Routing to the Production Order Operation.

Custom Fields Production Routing

 You can find a detailed implementation documentation here: Controlling, Scheduling, and Costing of Production Using Custom Fields in Routing Based on AVC

Integration of Change Documents

In the Maintain Bill of Material (Version 2) app, the Change Documents tab is added:

Viewing of change documents for BOMs

 

Business objects are changed frequently. It is often useful, and even necessary, to be able to trace the changes made. The tab displays change logs, you can always find out what was changed, when, and other details. You can export the details to an excel sheet which can help you to analyze errors. This tab is only enabled for active records and is not displayed for draft records. 

Import Sales Document Configuration

Whenever you want to configure a sales document item that is very similar to a previously configured one, you can import all of its user-assigned and external characteristic values into your draft configuration, thereby shortening the process.

Import Sales Document Configuration

To be able to import an existing configuration, your sales document must have the same root product as the one you want to import the configuration from. The function works with both single and multi-level configurations, but in a multi-level configuration, it always applies to the root product (importing level-by-level is not possible).

This demo was shown in our last Early Release Show: 

 

 

Export BOM Structure

The Export BOM Structure feature allows you to download the Bill of Materials (BOM) hierarchy displayed in the structure panel as a spreadsheet file. This enables detailed analysis of multi-level configuration models, such as those in sales orders or configuration simulations. For example, you can use the exported data to compare different configured BOM states or for other analytical purposes.

Export BOM Structure

 The key features include: 

  • You can use the export table button in the structure panel to generate a spreadsheet file containing the BOM hierarchy with its key attributes. The downloaded file includes a fixed set of attributes, regardless of which fields are currently displayed in the BOM view.

  • Available in all processes where the structure panel is displayed for a multi-level configuration, such as a sales order, an order BOM with an engineering-to-order scenario enabled, or a configuration simulation.

  • The export reflects the selected BOM explosion mode (e.g., toggling between Configured BOM and Super BOM views in the configuration simulation), and it always includes the complete BOM depth as defined by the explosion mode, regardless of how many levels are expanded in the user interface.

This demo was shown in our last Early Release Webinar: 

 

 

Production Planning 

User Authorization for Schedule Handover of Purchase Requisitions

App authorizations have been adjusted for the App authorizations have been adjusted for the Schedule Handover of Purchase Requisitions app.

Schedule Handover of Purchase Requisitions

This app manages access to activities related to scheduling application jobs for the automatic handover of purchase requisitions and their status. To access this app, you need to ensure that your business users have the following business catalog assigned with WRITE authorization for restriction type PP_MRP_CTRLR (MRP Controller): Production Planning - MRP Runs (SAP_SCM_BC_MRPRUN_MC) app.

Business Catalog ID: SAP_SCM_BC_MRPRUN_MC

 

Capacity Scheduling Board

You can enable Activity Coloring for the Setup, Process, and Teardown operations by enabling the Activity Coloring option in the App Settings window. This will enable you to differentiate between activities within an operation. You can also use this feature in the Manage Operation and Order Details page. 

Capacity scheduling board – Activity coloring

This feature is only available when Industry Type is selected as Discrete in the App Settings window.

This demo was shown during out last Early Release Webinar: 

 

 

Capacity Scheduling Table

With this feature, you can perform availability checks for components needed to complete your process or production orders. 

Component availability information for capacity scheduling table

The point in time of the automatic check depends on the configuration of your system. If you want to check the component availability again explicitly or if you want to reset quantities that have been committed by earlier checks, you can use the options for the component availability check.

This demo was shown during out last Early Release Webinar: 

 

 

Quality Management 

AI-Assisted Processing of Incoming Quality Certificates with SAP Document AI

With this feature, you can automatically process incoming quality certificate documents. The data of the quality certificates is extracted using SAP Document AI and, if possible, the quality certificates are automatically attached to the relevant certificate receipts. This allows you to handle certificates more efficiently and helps ensure that nothing is lost or overlooked.

AI-Assisted Processing of Incoming Quality Certificates with SAP Document AI

After quality certificates are uploaded using the new Upload Quality Certificate Documents app or by monitoring an email inbox, SAP Document AI extracts their data. The system checks this data against existing certificate receipts using a matching logic and takes the appropriate action:

  • If the system identifies a matching certificate receipt expecting a certificate, it attaches the certificate document to the receipt.
  • If it can be concluded that no matching certificate receipt exists, the system creates a new one
  • If the system cannot clearly identify or update the certificate receipt, you can review the extracted data and manually complete the matching process in the new Review Certificate Document Matches app.

This demo gives a great overview: 

 

My colleague Leonie Peterka has written the Quality Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 blog post. Here you will find all innovations. 

 

My Summary

In summary, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release embodies a significant leap forward in manufacturing capabilities especially in the area of Capacity Planning & Scheduling (CPS) as well as Quality Management with a very useful first AI use case. 

 

More Information

If you are interested in the latest and greatest blog posts on Manufacturing, please have a look at my collection blog and also take a look at the Community page for Manufacturing.

 

 

Watch the Replays of Our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series!   

From July 21 to July 25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand – anywhere, anytime. 

  

 

Find All of Our Assets   

We at Cloud ERP Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Revolutionizing Technical Specification Document With AI Assisted ERP Tool
entry.content:
Use of CEREBRO CODE ASSIT in Technical Specification Document (TSD)

What is Technical Specification (TS)

Technical specs translate business requirements into concrete technical blueprints for SAP developers. They ensure a clear understanding of the solution logic, components and integration paths.

It serves as a roadmap for the development team, ensuring everyone is on the same page and working towards a common goal. 

Technical Specification Stages

Every TS typically includes the following sections:

  • Input & output Parameter
  • Processing logic
  • Program logic
  • Interfaces and Data flows
  • Tables and DDSC elements
  • Function modules and Enhancements
  • ABAP Artifacts

Challenges in creating TSD using classical approach (without AI assistance)

1. Time-Consuming Documentation

  • Manual writing and formatting take significant time.
  • Repetitive sections (e.g., similar specs for different modules) require duplicate effort.
  • Lack of automation increases the time needed to complete specs.

2. Human Errors and Inconsistencies

  • Typos, version mismatches, and inconsistent terminology are common.
  • Difficult to maintain accuracy across cross-functional teams.
  • Missed fields or incomplete specs can cause development issues later.

3. Lack of Standardization

  • Different authors may follow different styles and formats.
  • Inconsistent use of templates or naming conventions.
  • Makes it harder for developers and testers to interpret the specs clearly.

4. Poor Requirement Mapping

  • Difficulty in linking business requirements (from functional specs) to technical solutions.
  • Manual traceability can lead to gaps or misunderstandings.
  • Changes in requirements often not reflected correctly in the tech spec.

5. Difficulty in Knowledge Reuse

  • No intelligent suggestion system to recommend previous similar solutions or code snippets.
  • Re-inventing the wheel each time, even for similar use cases.

6. Collaboration Issues

  • Inefficient collaboration between consultants, developers, and testers.
  • Comments and feedback are often tracked manually (emails, spread sheets).
  • No centralized smart system to manage versions and approvals.

7. Delayed Impact Analysis

  • Manual assessment of how a change in one module affects other areas.
  • Increases risk of missing downstream effects.

8. Poor Integration with DevOps

  • No intelligent integration between spec documents and development environments.
  • Manual handoffs lead to missed technical details during implementation.

9. Lack of Real-time Validation

  • No support for validating logic, syntax, or dependencies while writing specs.
  • Issues often found later in development or testing stages.

Cerebro Code Assist

AI-assisted ERP alters how we think about SAP development. By automating integration tasks that once took days or even weeks, AI solutions allow developers to perform faster, smarter, and more reliable integrations.

Cerebro SASA represents one such solution that demonstrates the power of AI in ERP development by helping organizations save time, minimize manual effort, and improve consistency and uniformity between multiple integration projects.

As AI is growing faster then ever, its role in SAP ERP Solutions will only become more vital, making it an essential part of the future of enterprise software development.

TSD Generation using Cerebro SAP Code Assist Driven

Step 1 Translating FS into TS using AI

Cerebro reads your approved FS and starts generating a technical draft by interpreting functional logic into technical flow diagrams and pseudo code.

Step 2 Input, Output and solution details.

It suggests structured input, output fields, processing logic, validations, and integration flows, reducing the burden of documentation from scratch.

Step 3 Referencing SAP objects.

Cerebro also identifies and embeds references to real SAP artifacts such as DDC objects, CDs, views, RAP elements, and ABAP modules.

Enhancing Technical clarity

Step 1 Cross checking with developers.

Cerebro enables collaborative reviews by sharing TS drafts with developers and architects for instant feedback.

Step 2 Identifying risks and gaps using dependency tracing.

Cerebro flags missing logic, incompatible structures, or interface mismatches to ensure technical soundness.

Step 3 Finalizing with code snippets.

Once validated, the document can be enhanced with sample ABAP snippets, naming conventions and export ready formatting.

Finally Cerebro accelerates TS documentation, transforming high level business specs into structured technical blueprints.

Overcoming TSD challenges with Cerebro Code Assist

 

1. Automated Drafting of Technical Specs

Cerebro can auto-generate initial drafts of technical specifications based on:

  • Functional specification documents
  • Tables to be used
  • ABAP programs or enhancements needed
  • Interfaces involved
  • Data mapping suggestions

2. Template Standardization and Document Formatting

Cerebro can ensure that all technical specs follow a standard template and formatting guideline, reducing manual errors and inconsistencies.

  • Enforces naming conventions
  • Uniform section headers and numbering
  • Highlights missing sections automatically

3. Code Snippet Generation

Cerebro can generate sample ABAP code, user exits, BADI templates, or even CDS views based on the technical requirements described in the document.

For Example:

Given a requirement for a custom report on sales orders, AI can generate a base SELECT statement on VBAK and VBAP tables and structure the report output.

4. Automated Impact Analysis

Cerebro can scan SAP systems to identify objects affected by a change and suggest what needs to be included in the technical spec.

For Example:

“Changing field X in Table Y impacts the Z-report and the P-user exit.” AI can include this impact summary directly in the spec.

5. Review and Error Detection

Cerebro can help validate technical specs by:

  • Detecting inconsistencies between functional and technical documents
  • Flagging missing object references
  • Checking compliance with SAP development standards

 

Conclusion:

The next decade will define humanity’s relationship with artificial intelligence. The focus must shift from mere performance gains to trustworthy, efficient, and aligned intelligence. With careful coordination across technical, ethical, and societal dimensions, AI can become a force for extraordinary progress.

Regards,

NAVNEET DARAK

Senior SAP BW4 HANA Consultant

entry.title: Re: Asset filed is not available in the import supplier i...
entry.content:
Hello @Naveenk_S42024 

Thanks for confirming the release and for the screenshot.

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2508, the Import Supplier Invoices (F3041) Excel template supports only header and G/L account item fields. Asset and Asset sub number columns are not available, so asset-assigned vendor invoices cannot be uploaded via this template.

What you should do instead

A) Post asset acquisitions without PO (integrated with A/P)

  • App: Manage Supplier Invoices – Advanced
  • Function: Post Acquisition – Integrated with Accounts Payable (without Purchase Order)
  • Enter header data → add item → choose Account Assignment = Asset, enter Asset and Sub number, simulate, Post.

B) With a Purchase Order

  • Create a PO with Account Assignment Category = Asset (A) and enter Asset/sub number on the PO item.
  • Post the supplier invoice with PO reference (Manage/Create Supplier Invoices). The asset assignment flows from the PO.

C) True mass creation

  • Use the Supplier Invoice API (API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV) to generate invoices with asset account posting. This is the recommended method if you need to load many asset-assigned invoices in 2508.

Let me know if you need further support

With regard

Chuma

 

GenAI assist contents

SAP official documentation

  • SAP Help Portal  Import Supplier Invoices (F3041) template covers header and  G/L items only.
  • SAP Help Portal — Manage Supplier Invoices – Advanced: Post Acquisition – Integrated with Accounts Payable (without PO).
  • SAP Help Portal / Fiori Apps Library — Create/Manage Supplier Invoices (with PO reference).
  • SAP API Business Hub — API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV (guide/sample for asset account posting).

entry.title: Re: "Project Manager" Field in Project Control - Enterpri...
entry.content:
Hello @manickath 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

In SAP EPPM Public Cloud, the Project Manager field in Project Control Enterprise Projects shows all business users by default.
To limit this to a small set of users, for example a range of 3-4

Please note that direct filtering is limited in Public Cloud but you can control it via role assignments. Only assign the Project Manager role to desired users.

Alternatively, you can use Field Control or a custom CDS view or UI adaptation if available to restrict the list.

On‑premise offers you more customizing options e.g., SPRO à PPM à Field Control, whereas in Public Cloud role‑based filtering is the practical approach.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Simple Signavio Question about Audiences and One abou...
entry.content:
Hi,

you can link a user group to your new Audience and customize in Settings (Collab Hub Settings) what this Audience gets to see. There are quite a few set-ups related to Audiences. And to answer directly to your questions: the users of an Audience can see the content set up for this Audeince. But there can be users that are part of more groups and if these groups are linked to different Audiences, than the users will be able to change between the Audiences.

You can create the groups yourself(as  Admin), in this case you would create the group according to your business unit and add the members of your business unit to this group. As well you can set up their user rights with what they are allowed to see or which actions are they allowed to do. I recommend to establish a concept for user rights before starting all this.  

Regarding SSO, I have tried both alternatives with and without groups, the one with groups always had issues, this was some time ago, maybe it was fixed by now.  you can work with groups, you need to set this up in your IdP.  You can find all instructions in SAP Help. 

I hope I could help! Best

Rada

entry.title: Re: CDS/API/BADI to populate CUP and CIG fields in Itly t...
entry.content:
Hello @Gahan_Narayan1 

The Italian-specific CUP (Codice Unico di Progetto) and CIG (Codice Identificativo Gara) fields on the PO item › Italy tab are not yet exposed in any released artefacts, no public CDS view, no released OData API for PO items, and no PO-item BAdI parameters to read or write them. That’s why you cannot find them, and why they cannot be populated programmatically from a contract or requisition today. Entry remains manual in the UI.

You are not exposed to;

  • Any released CDS view
  • API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV or other public APIs
  • PO-item level BAdIs

They are UI-only fields, so they can’t be populated programmatically from PR/Contract.

Possible Workaround:

  • Create custom fields YY_CUP / YY_CIG on PR/Contract/PO via Custom Fields and Logic.
  • Use standard field transfer or MM_PUR_S4_PO_ITEM (Determine Fields) BAdI where available for custom fields.
  • Use custom CDS views/queries for reporting and include in PO output forms.

If the standard CUP/CIG population is mandatory:

Raise an SAP incident requesting these fields be:

  • Added to a released PO-item CDS view
  • Exposed in API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV
  • Available in a released PO-item BAdI

SAP Help – CUP and CIG Fields in Italy Localisation for Purchase Orders: explains field purpose and manual maintenance in Public Cloud.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: FG TO RM NORMS CONSUMPTION
entry.content:
Consider the below tables to develop a custom report

  1. To start with FG material, use MAST to get BOM number (STLNR) for the FG
  2. For BOM Header, use STKO with STLNR to get BOM usage, plant, etc.
  3. For BOM items, use STPO with STLNR to get RM components and quantities
  4. For each RM in STPO, check if it is SFG. If yes, repeat steps 1–3 above to explode its BOM
  5. Continue until all leaf-level RMs are reached

entry.title: List Item Not Repeating Data in SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I'm trying to create a simple list view to display the item's warehouse availability, similar to how SAP B1 does in the Stock tab of Item Master Data in SAP Business One.

In there, basic fields such as warehouse code, in stock, committed, and ordered. The input comes from a scanned barcode, which in turn is associated with the Item Master. Fetching header-level data is fine. I managed to get Item Code, Item Name, and I could get any other data from the same level. But when it comes to nested data, in this case, warehouse data related to the item, I got stuck. I describe how I set up the data source and how I am managing data/page variables:

Data Source

In this system, we are using SAP Cloud Connector to link BTP to our On-Premise landscape. We created a destination called SBOSL, which points to the Service Layer root endpoint, whereby all exposed entities can be used. SBOSL then gets available as data source in SAP Build Apps, and all I had to do was enabling the entities I wanted to work with. In this case, Items. It seems to be a rather straightforward manner to source data, as we have no need to create and manage API calls by setting up headers, body, parameter, etc. Everything is handled through the UI.

Data Variables

I have set a data variable called itemByBarcode, from the type "Collection of data records". Here, I configured a filter condition (where Barcode = scannedBarcode), and the fields as List of Values (ItemCode, ItemName, BarCode, ItemWarehouseInfoCollection).

Logic

The current logic consists on:

  1. Scan Barcode
  2. Store the scanned barcode in the page variable scannedBarcode
  3. Get Record Collection by using scannedBarcode variable
  4. Bind a data variable node to the itemByBarcode data variable

List Item

We added a list item called Warehouse List, and bind the "Repeat With" property to the formula data.itemByBarcode[0].ItemWarehouseInfoCollection. Inside of the list item, we placed a row with 4 cells, and each cell includes a text element where the warehouse data goes in (warehouse code, in stock, committed, ordered). The tree points to Row > Cell > Text, so there is no container aggregating the elements, which could potentially block the data flow.

The problem is that, even setting up the repeater in the outer list, I cannot see the individual fields to bind to each warehouse field, such as warehouse code, in stock, and so on. I tried to hardcode it via formula (e.g. current.WhsCode), but it doesn't work, as expected.

Also tried to bind via Data Item to repeat, and the nested data (Item > ItemWarehouseInfoCollection) doesn't appear to be available.

Outcomes

When previewing the App, at least I can see that the quantity of lines printed matches SAP. I even added a text to debug how many records are being fetch (quantity of warehouses), and it also matches (5), but the data itself still doesn't show up in the list.

Any comments or insights would be greatly appreciated! Thanks in anticipation!

BR,
Felipe

entry.title: Re: Delivery group functionality in Sales order item leve...

Please note the field VBAP-GRKOR (Delivery Group) does not trigger delivery split by itself in standard SAP. Instead, it is used to group items together that must be delivered in the same delivery, not to split them.

According to SAP Note 546668:

Delivery splits are triggered by differences in key fields that populate the delivery header. These include shipping point, route, incoterms, delivery date, and custom fields like ZUKRL,  but GRKOR is not a standard split criterion.

As suggested in the note, what you can do is you can pass the value to ZUKRL, based on GRKOR via copy control routine in Sales Order > Delivery. This field is used by SAP to force delivery splits. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you may need to use the BAdI SD_DELIVERY_SPLIT to implement custom split logic. This allows you to define your own criteria; including GRKOR, for splitting deliveries.

In short, the summary is

entry.title: TDS Configuration and deduction under Section 194C
entry.content:
• What configuration steps are required in SAP to enable both transaction-wise and annual cumulative TDS deduction as per Section 194C?
  • How do we set threshold limits for ₹30,000 per transaction and ₹1,00,000 annually?
  • Are there specific settings in Withholding Tax Type, Withholding Tax Code, or Condition Records that need to be updated? 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: TDS Configuration and deduction under Section 194C
entry.content:
Hi all,

 

TDS is deducted for 194C section if:

  • A single payment/invoice exceeds ₹30,000 (₹15,000 in case of payments to individual/HUF contractors for supply of labor).

  • Or the aggregate payments in a financial year to the same contractor exceed ₹1,00,000 (₹75,000 in case of payments to individual/HUF contractors for supply of labor).

 

Please find the below mandatory configuration activity,

104229 ---->>> Define Withholding Tax Keys

104225 ---->>> Define Withholding Tax Type for Invoice Posting

104226 ---->>> Define Withholding Tax Type for Payment Posting

104227 ---->>> Define Withholding Tax Codes

 

To use standard accumulation for TDS, assign the appropriate Withholding Tax Type and Code to the vendor using the 'Maintain Business Partner (Supplier)' app. Navigate to the Company Code view → Withholding Tax Data → Withholding Tax tab, and maintain the relevant TDS details.

 

Kindly note, we don't have exemption limit at transaction level for 194C section. TAN based exemptions cannot be used.

 

Best regards,

Atanu

SAP Support - S/4HANA Cloud

entry.title: AI-Assisted Calculations in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce the arrival of AI-Assisted Calculations in SAP Analytics Cloud—a transformative new feature designed to enhance your interaction with data. As part of our broader "AI First" strategy, this innovation harnesses generative AI to revolutionize how you create and comprehend complex calculations within the Calculation Dialog in SAP Analytics Cloud’s Data Analyzer, streamlining your data workflows and boosting analytical efficiency.

What Is It? 

AI-Assisted Calculations consists of two key functionalities within the calculation dialog: Generate and Explain. The Generate functionality simplifies the process of creating calculations by allowing you to use natural language to create a new calculation. The Explain functionality helps you understand existing calculations by providing a clear, natural language explanation. 

Key Benefits 

  1. Accelerate Calculation Creation: Instantly generate complex formulas using natural language queries, significantly reducing the time required for creating calculations and speeding up your workflow. 
  1. Simplify Calculation Understanding: Use the "Explain" feature to translate existing formulas into simple, easy-to-understand language, facilitating quick comprehension of complex calculations from colleagues or your own work. 
  1. Enhance User Experience: Leverage AI to simplify formula creation and explanation, making data analysis more intuitive and user-friendly, with future enhancements to resolve formula errors efficiently. 

How It Works

Generating a Calculation

The Generate functionality is a game-changer, allowing users to create complex calculations by simply describing what they need, rather than manually constructing formulas.

  1. In the Create Calculation or Edit Calculation dialog, open AI-Assisted Calculations. 
  2. In the formula requirement field, type your request using natural language. For example: "Calculate the Gross Margin Ratio" or "I need a formula to flag percentage values that deviate from the budget by more than 6%." 

  3. Click Generate. The AI will display a generated formula that you can review. 

  4. Once you're satisfied with the result, click Copy to Formula to use it in your calculation. 

Tip: For optimal accuracy in your calculations, provide clear and detailed requirements. Specify the exact dimensions and measures, and identify the specific members you are referring to. This precision will enhance the reliability of the generated calculations. 

Explaining a Calculation

The Explain functionality is perfect for understanding complex formulas created by others or refreshing your memory on your own work. 

  1. In the Edit Calculation dialog, the formula will appear in both the editor and the AI-Assisted Calculations tab. 
  2. Click Explain in the AI-Assisted Calculations. 
  3. The assistant will provide a clear, natural-language explanation of what the formula does. 

 This is especially helpful for understanding the business purpose behind a calculation and can be used to write a better description for the calculation itself, or just to understand it. 

Prerequisites 

This feature is part of the broader AI-Assisted Features suite in SAC and requires: 

  • A valid SAC license (BI or Planning) 
  • Business AI. See SAP Note 0003491182 . 
  • You must have purchased the SAP AI Units license. Please read the SAP Business AI catalog for more information, including factors for converting usage into SAP AI Units 
  • You must have the Execute permission for the Generative AI privilege. 

You can check that you have met all the necessary prerequisites, including activating the feature, as detailed here. . 

Looking Forward

This functionality will soon be available in the calculation editor within Story in SAP Analytics Cloud through the new Calculation Dialog. It holds immense potential for broader SAC implementations, especially where automated calculation creation is needed. We are committed to enhancing user workflows through continuous improvements and welcome your feedback and collaboration as part of our AI First strategy for SAC.

Thank you for your interest in AI-Assisted Calculations. We hope this new capability enhances your data analytics experience and invite your insights and feedback.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud - Data Actions - Advance Formula...
entry.content:
Hi @PS_1978

The statements for NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"), NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"), and NEXT( 0, "MONTH") can't be eliminated due to IF Condition [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Mar", "Jul", "Sep", and "Dec". 

Please refer to the script below, which eliminates script redundancy.

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/MEASURE_TYPE], [d/HRPOSITION], [d/GL_ACCOUNT], [d/DATASRC], [d/COSTCENTER]
CONFIG.HIERARCHY = [d/COSTCENTER].[h/DA_Prompt_H1]
MEMBERSET [d/DATASRC] = "UPLOAD"
MEMBERSET [d/CURRENCY] = "USD"
// MEMBERSET [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "EMP_SALARY"
MEMBERSET [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = ("GL_1", "GL_2")
MEMBERSET [d/DATASRC] = (CALC - REG, CALC - MERIT)
MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "SALARY"
MEMBERSET [d/COMPANY] = %SelectCompany%
MEMBERSET [d/EMPCATE] = ("Full Time", "New", "Part Time")
MEMBERSET [d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH", %CutOffMonth%) TO NEXT(%NumberOfMonths%, "MONTH", %CutOffMonth%)

IF [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Mar" OR [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Jun" OR [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Sep" OR [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Dec"
	THEN
	IF [d/HRPOSITION].[p/NEWPOS_FLAG] = "Y" THEN
		// For the New employee % to be read from assumption Table	
		DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_SALARIED") =
		  (RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
		* (RESULTLOOKUP([d/MEASURE_TYPE] = [d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_GRADE], [d/DATASRC] = "INPUT", [d/Measures] = "PERCENTAGE", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "#", [d/CURRENCY] = "#", [d/COSTCENTER] = "#", [d/HRPOSITION] = "#", [d/EMPLOYEE] = "#", [d/START_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/END_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/SHIFT] = "#", [d/TERM_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/GRADE] = "#", [d/EMPCATE] = "#", [d/EMPSTAT] = "#", [d/LABOR_TYPE] = "#"))
	ELSE
		// For the existing employee % to be read from emp attribute	
		DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_SALARIED") =
		 ((RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
		 * (ATTRIBUTE([d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_BONUS]))) / 100
	ENDIF
ENDIF

I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: How to get single property from a nested structure using $select in Odata API Call
entry.content:
Hi there,

without accessing an SAP system right now, I've tried to replicate the behavior using the Northwind V4 service. As far as I know (though be it unverified) the V4 Northwind API isn't fully V4 compliant so take the result with a grain of salt.

I took the base query of `https://services.odata.org/v4/northwind/northwind.svc/Orders?$expand=Order_Details` so that I can replicate your nested scenario (is that is what you meant by nested entity(?), again sorry I currently don't have access to an SAP system).

Now I added the `$select` to the expand (nested property) so that I may retrieve only a subset of properties. That now looks like this, using: `https://services.odata.org/v4/northwind/northwind.svc/Orders?$select=OrderID&$expand=Order_Details($select=ProductID)`. 

If you're looking at complex types or collection of complex types wrt nesting, please have a look at the V4 OData specification (which is awesome) at: https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata/v4.01/odata-v4.01-part2-url-conventions.html#sec_SystemQueryOptionselect more specifically maybe "Example 130" is what you're looking for.

Hth~ Marco

entry.title: Re: Unable to find delivery event
entry.content:
Hi All,

In 2025, we still can reproduce this issue. At the end of the error description, the solution is given (with a minor error) :

  1. go to Tcode SNOTE
  2. go the menu "Environment", and select the action "Download delivery events"
  3. finally retry your operations in SPAU.
